frame.name: Surrounding
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> surrounds a <fen>Ground</fen>. The <fen>Ground</fen> location is presented as more likely to be a known location than the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>. Some lexical units entail more-or-less complete surrounding in two or three dimensions (e.g. surround.v), while others entail surrounding on only two sides (e.g. astride.prep, straddle.v). Like other locative relations, the <fen>Figure</fen> may be any of a movable entity, an immovable entity, or an event.
<ex><fex name="Figure">The hand</fex> <t>around</t> <fex name="Ground">the sword-hilt</fex> was no less impressive than the sword .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">The drug war</fex> <t>straddles</t> <fex name="Ground">the border of the US and Mexico</fex> .</ex>
This frame resembles the Adorning frame, in that both involve a <fen>Figure</fen> "covering" some <fen>Ground</fen>, but the Surrounding frame differs in that the <fen>Profiled_region</fen> is not coextensive with the <fen>Ground</fen>, as it is in the Adorning frame, and, in fact, unusually for a locative relation, the <fen>Ground</fen> entity is normally smaller than the <fen>Figure</fen>. For this reason, the verbs of this frame are often used in the passive (restoring the normal relationship of stative subjects to oblique elements). <ex></ex> In addition to several lexical units of this frame originating as metaphorical extentions of much more specific posture descriptions (straddle.v, astride.prep), this frame is itself used in a productive metaphor, involving abstract entities metaphorically "impinging" on other entities (in terms of derivative similarity, control, etc.), as in the following: <ex>that led to Dolce and Gabbana to <fex name="Figure">base their autumn/winter D and G collection</fex> <t>around</t> <fex name="Ground">her style</fex> in 2008</ex> <ex>But he discovered that <fex name="Ground">the literary world</fex> was a battlefieldâ€” mined with hatred, <t>rimmed</t> <fex name="Figure">with snipers</fex>. </ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">Countless legends</fex> sprung up <t>around</t> <fex name="Ground">the knight</fex>.</ex>
Common abstract entities that serve as <fen>Figure</fen> include emotions ('the hopelessness <t>surrounding</t> them'), as well as theories, arguments, and collective philosophies ('Ageism <t>surrounds</t> us, but passes largely unnoticed'). This metaphor arises from the normal invited implicature of this frame that the <fen>Figure</fen> may physically impinge on the <fen>Ground</fen>, either protecting it, or limiting its motion, or even supporting it.</def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is the entity located with respect to the <fen>Ground</fen>.
<ex>He had <fex name="Figure">both hands</fex> wrapped <t>around</t> her arm .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> is the area that the <fen>Figure</fen> surrounds.</def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Figure</fen> is located around the <fen>Ground</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Direction">Up</fex> <t>around</t> the bolt she saw a frayed noose .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Distance</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and some reference location (generally, the deictic center or the <fen>Ground</fen>).
WARNING: Probably not relevant for this frame.</def-root>

FE.name: Profiled_region
FE.definition:
<def-root>The area or zone immediately external to the <fen>Ground</fen>. This FE excludes <fen>Figure</fen> and is only used in particular constructions such as the following:
<ex>We looked <fex name="Profiled_region"><t>around</t></fex> the trees .</ex>
</def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, and directly.
<ex>A single membrane <fex name="Directness">directly</fex> <t>surrounds</t> the cytoplasm.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how accessible the <fen>Figure</fen> is to some participant in the speech context (either the speaker or the addressee, or some other highly salient viewpoint in a narrative). This FE normally describes availability for manipulation and use, but may simply describe how easily seen the <fen>Figure</fen> is. There is a closed class of items that can fill this slot, including only 'just' and 'right' indicating ease of access.
<ex>The skittles lie <fex name="Accessibility">just</fex> <t>around</t> their empty package.</ex></def-root>
